story: Dorothy Tervit was presented the purse of specially minted coins by Her Majesty The Queen at a ceremony before Easter weekend.Dorothy, from Laburnum Avenue, told the Courier: ldquoWhen the invitation came through in November, I thought it was a hoax!ldquoI thought lsquowhy on earth would Buckingham Palace be writing to me rsquoThe -year-old, who is a member of the local community choir, the local history society and Chalmers Memorial Church, was nominated by an anonymous supporter.The nominator has to be a Christian minister and the recipient is not allowed to know their identity, though Dorothy has some ideas.She said: ldquoUsing the process of elimination, I could make an educated guess.ldquoIrsquom so grateful, though, as the whole experience was absolutely wonderful ndash a real once-in-a-letime moment.The Royal Maundy refers to the service where the British Monarch distributes small purses full of coins called Maundy money as symbolic alms to the nominated recipients. It is a ceremony thought to date back to the Middle Ages and took place at St Georgersquos Chapel in Windsor.The coins are presented in two leather purses, a white one containing coins to the value of the same number of pence as the years of the monarchrsquos age, and a red purse containing a pound and a p coin.Dorothy was one of  recipients. As the Queen is  years old, there are  female recipients and  male recipients, as well as  pence worth of special silver coins in one of the purses.The other purse presented included a commemorative pound coin marking the th anniversary of Queen Victoriarsquos birth.Dorothy attended the ceremony last week with her husband Tom.She added: ldquoThe Queen was so gracious, I felt undeserving. We werenrsquot allowed to speak to her, as per the rules, but she had such a warm smile for everyone in line for the purse.

title: cinema-planned-along-with-holiday-lodges-at-archerfield
story: Caledonian Heritable is keen to further develop Archerfield via a dozen two-bedroom cabins, as well as extending Fletcherrsquos Cottage Spa and creating a cinema and additional conference facilities. If approved, two new homes would also be built on the sitersquos eastern boundary, near Dirleton.A supporting statement included in a planning application to East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe Bank of Scotland has been funding the previous expansion of Archerfield and in addition we have been contributing part of the monies raised from selling the [housing] plots at Archerfield.ldquoIt has been quite challenging financing Archerfield up to this point and it has been most beneficial that the [housing] plots at Kings Cairn are now managing to pay back some of the financial support given to us by the Bank of Scotland. To enable the proposed increase in the number of hotel bedrooms [cabins], extensions to the spa and laundry facilities etc, we need to give the bank further comfort to continue supporting our ambition to build Archerfield into Scotlandrsquos premier hotel accommodation with a top-of-the-range spa, golf courses, conference facilities, cinema etc.ldquoThe bank has security over all the property and land at Archerfield but we now need them to extend our facility to allow us to finance the poundm projected costs.If given the green light, the project would also result in further jobs being created with  per cent more staff in line to be employed.Tom Drysdale, who lives in nearby Dirleton, is chairman of Gullane Area Community Council. He said there were concerns about the proposals, particularly regarding the two properties off Manse Road.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoDirleton Village Association has a very strong view on the matter and is supported by the community council.ldquoThis is part of a much bigger planning application, which involves new additional facilities in the Archerfield Links golfing estate, a signicant number of holiday lodges and aroom.ldquoThe community is not concerned about any of these items, other than two house lodges, right beside the village green in Dirleton. There is a very strong feel that this is completely inappropriate.ldquoThe proposal is to build two big two-storey houses, which would simply not fit into the village environment.Set in  acres, the Archerfield Estate is home to two golf courses and a iety of accommodation styles to rent, including grade one-listed Archerfield House.There is also a cafe, deli, food market, gt shop, bar and microbrewery at Archerfield Walled Garden.

title: tims-tales-wallaces-mutton-hole
story: AT THE tail end of the Easter weekend, I headed for Yellow Craig ndash not the beach, but the craggy small hill which gives the area its name.Itrsquos a volcanic vent, created millions of years ago, just like North Berwick Law nearby.But it canrsquot be compared to the Law. Itrsquos a tiny hill, and many people walk past without noticing it, as nature has covered much of it under a blanket of overgrowth.But close up Irsquove always thought it appears mysterious. It is made up of agglomerate, which is the remains of volcanic ash all mixed up with bits of other rock and stone, then solidied and compressed over millions of years.But in places the agglomerate rock looks like it could be the ancient rubble built walls of an old ruined castle. Steps now lead to the summit, and despite the smallness of the hill, the view from the top is quite spectacular.I could see Fidra Island basking in a shimmering sea when I climbed it in the evening of Easter Monday. I reflected that Robert Louis Stevenson must have once stood on this exact spot as he viewed what many say was his inspiration for Treasure Island.But my purpose that beautul evening was to find lsquoWallacersquos Mutton Holersquo. There was a local tradition that a small cave-like cavity on the north side of Yellow Craig bore this name, and although the origin of the tradition is lost, it was clearly linked to William Wallace.I found reference to this tradition in an old account from over  years ago in the Haddingtonshire Advertiser by a Mr Jamieson. However, it was brought to my mind when I read of the refurbishment of the Wallace Monument. As part of this, there will be the Luumlbeck letter on display, written by Wallace and sent to the merchants of Luumlbeck in .Wallace, it seems, was in East Lothian at the time this letter was composed. And it was this connection that sparked my memory of the reference to lsquoWallacersquos Mutton Holersquo on Yellow Craig and set me on my quest.But it was in the dying embers of the day we arrived, and I had limited time to explore. The kids had fallen asleep in the car and I think my long-suffering we was content to relax while I scrambled around a rock at the tail end of a fun but exhausting day.As I headed through the wood alone to the craig, the sun was already beginning to lower its head. The sound of birdsong was a crescendo naturersquos melody for spring.Yellow Craig wood isnrsquot ancient, most trees are around  years old. But there are some, mostly sycamores, which are clearly much older. They have exotic shapes and their twisted limbs and scaled bark make them look like fossilised dragons. Perhaps they are. There is one which grows close to the play park that even looks like a serpent.These older trees give this wood an ancient feel. There are also Scots pines, mostly along the edge of the wood. They are descendants of the great Caledonian Forest which once covered most of the north of Scotland. Patches of emigrant Scots pine can be found all over East Lothian and at Yellow Craig they seem to guard the wood from northerly gales, and they are bent and shaped by the wind.Scots pines also stand guard at Yellow Craig itself. When I arrived I didnrsquot initially head up the steps but scrambled up the northern slope, looking for Wallacersquos Mutton Hole.The meaning of this term is a subject of debate, and I claim no academic authority, but I wonderit could come from the term lsquomootrsquo, which is an old Anglo-Saxon word meaning debate or discussion. A moot hall was a room for this purpose in a medieval building, but Wallace was a guerilla fighter, so could this meeting place have been his moot ha If this was so, perhaps Yellow Craig was a meeting place, where Wallace and his followers once met to discuss strategy. Could the idea of the letter to Luumlbeck have been decided here, as they cast their eyes across the sea from the vantage of the rock Itrsquos an interesting idea, but of course therersquos no historical evidence for it. Yet most of what actually happened in those times has no historical evidence.I couldnrsquot find the hole or hollow, as nature has claimed the slope and thick vegetation meant I was kept away from the recesses hidden behind. Perhaps winter would have been a better time to search.But I was not disappointed. I sat on the summit and my instinct told me there was a mystery here that remains untold. A scant and seemingly forgotten oral tradition is not much to go on. But often an ancient half-whispered tradition has grown from a seed of truth.There is a similar East Lothian connection to Wallace in the Garleton Hills. I have written of the Wallace Cave there and the traditions associated with it. There is enough connection to our national hero in East Lothian to say our landscape can also claim connection to him.I will search deeper for references to Wallacersquos Mutton Hole at Yellow Craig andmy findings to this pagemy search proves fruitful. But regardless of the results of this search, for me Yellow Craig will always be a place of magic contemplation and imaginative possibilities.

title: worlds-oldest-golf-scorecard-from-musselburgh-up-for-auction
story: Estimated at pound,-,, the card, which has been framed and mounted, dates from December , .It shows that a Mr Cundell played the five holes within the Musselburgh race track twice, a total of  holes in  strokes. Charmingly, the golfer provided his own commentary in a handwritten note at the bottom of the card: ldquoDreadful storm of wind and rain ndash atmosphere quite yellow ndash just like the lurid regions of Pandemonium.Mr Cundell is almost certainly James Cundell, who was closely involved with the Thistle Golf Club since its founding in  and who published one of the first ever rule books of golf in .Kevin McGimpsey, Bonhamsrsquo golfing memorabilia consultant, said: ldquoThis original scorecard is in remarkable condition considering its age and the atrocious weather conditions at the time Mr Cundell played his round.ldquoIt has an excellent provenance, having once belonged to the well-known golfer Sir Henry Cotton, who kept it in his renowned Black Tin Box with other rare examples of historical golfing memorabilia.ldquoThe scorecard predates the oldest cards owned by the international golf museums.The scorecard will be auctioned at Bonhamsrsquo next sporting sale at its  Queen Street saleroom on Wednesday, which will present Part II of The Pierre Horwitz Collection of golfing memorabilia. This covers the period from the early part of the th century to the s and concentrates especially on the manufacture of clubs and balls and rare patented designs of both.Other highlights include: a white painted feather golf ball, handmade in about  by Allan Robertson, one of the most gted of the early professional golfers and a long nosed scared neck putter from about - made by Robert Forgan. The Pierre Horwitz collection Part I made a total of pound, last October.Documentary evidence proves that golf was played on Musselburgh Links as early as  although Mary, Queen of Scots reputedly played there in .

title: 110000-boost-for-musselburgh-charitys-work
story: The funding to the Bridges Centre, awarded over three years, will go towards the salary costs of a full-time personal development worker to deliver a programme of inidual and small group support to --year-olds.This will help young people develop their skills and aspirations for the future as the service seeks to build their emotional resilience and help them create positive relationships, enabling them to achieve their full potential.The grant, which was allocated through Children in Needrsquos Main Grants Programme, is its first funding allocation of the year, with additional cash-aid being distributed to projects across the UK throughout .Jim Boyle, chief executive of the Bridges Project, which is based on Musselburghrsquos Bogpark Road, said: ldquoWersquove been receiving funding from BBC Children in Need now for the last  years and, in that time, have been able to make a dference to hundreds of young peoplersquos lives.ldquoWersquore delighted that wersquoll be able to continue this for another three years in collaboration with our partners in education, social work, health and the voluntary sector.Florence Burke, national head of Scotland at BBC Children in Need, said: ldquoWe are delighted to fund the work of the Bridges Project and look forward to seeing the dference that this grant will make to children and young people across the region.Simon Antrobus, BBC Children in Needrsquos chief executive, added: ldquoAs always, thanks must go to our generous supporters and fundraisers. We are only able to make these much-needed awards because of them.In East Lothian and Midlothian, BBC Children in Need is currently funding nine projects to a value of pound,.Across Scotland, it has more than pound. million invested in projects making a positive dference to the lives of disadvantaged young people.For information on how to apply for funding, visit bbc pudsey grants

title: young-county-ballet-prodigy-gets-tuition-from-dance-star
story: Maisie Belle Black was trained for the day in Edinburgh by Danish dancer, choreographer and director Peter Schaufuss.The -year-old started learning at Dunbar School of Dance at the age of three and now trains with Scottish Ballet and the Edinburgh Ballet.She said: ldquoI love dancing. It gives me the freedom to express myself and I particularly enjoy the technical precision of ballet.ldquoI currently train several times a week but am always looking for more opportunities to dance and perform.Maisie, a student at Mary Erskine School, has already competed in many competitions including the Dance World Cup and Thatrsquos Showbiz.She had attended workshops at Edinburgh Festival Ballet School last year and jumped at the chance to work with the world-famous ballet dancer.She added: ldquoIrsquod heard a lot about Peter Schaufuss and his son Luke before as they are both very well-known.ldquoGetting to work with Peter was an amazing opportunity and I really enjoyed it.The famous dancer Schaufuss has performed and directed all over the world with leading companies including Kirov Ballet, Paris Opera Ballet, Royal Ballet and New York City Ballet, as well as founding The English National Ballet School.He said: ldquoThe masterclass presents an opportunity for Scottish dancers to spend a day learning from those that have been at the highest level of the dance profession.ldquoItrsquos an opportunity for students to be taught by some of the leading figures from the dance world and to learn what it takes to be a professional dancer.The class itself was designed by Schaufuss, who has plans to have a full-time school up and running from September based at St Stephenrsquos Church in Stockbridge, Edinburgh.Maisie added: ldquoMy ultimate dream is to be a professional dancer and perform every day.

title: magazine-aims-to-entice-new-haddington-residents-into-town-centre
story: Businesses in the town centre have joined forces to work on a magazine entitled lsquoMy Haddingtonrsquo.Moira Graham, of Haddington Business Community Partnership , said: ldquoWe are proposing to put together a one-off glossy magazine. We are going to run , copies aimed at the new housing.ldquoWith lots of local community members, our community groups are going to write their own editorials and tell us a little about what happens in Haddington.Members of HBCP, including award-winning Blooming Haddington, Friends of the River Tyne and ious sports groups, have been asked to contribute to the magazine, which will be A size.Mrs Graham added: ldquoAll the groups are going to have a wee say in it.ldquoA lot of people know what a great place Haddington is to live and work.ldquoWe are aiming to publish in the summer.Work is already under way to build more than  new homes at Letham Mains, between Haddingtonrsquos West Road and Pencaitland Road.Similarly, more than  new homes are being built at Dovecot, to the south of Pencaitland Road.Business representatives have repeatedly stressed the importance of attracting new residents into the centre to boost the local economy.The proposed magazine was highlighted at Haddingtonrsquos community council meeting and received the backing of long-standing chairwoman Jan Wilson.She described Haddington as ldquoa beautul town, steeped in history.Mrs Wilson said: ldquoLet us hope it will bring people into the town to use the town centre.ldquoIf this magazine can bring people together and make them aware of the things going on in the town it has to be a good thing.

title: interview-scotland-secretary-david-mundell-on-independence-brexit-and-david-cameron
story: David Cameronrsquos coalition beefed up Holyroodrsquos tax-ying abilities after implementing the recommendations of the Calman commission.A majority Conservative Government then accepted the post-indyref Smith Commission findings which gave the Parliament new tax and social security powers.The Tory politician who was involved with both sets of reforms was David Mundell, who in a twenty-year career in politics has served at Holyrood and Westminster.He was a junior Minister in the Scotland Office for the Calman legislation, and was Cameronrsquos Secretary of State of Scotland when the Smith proposals were turned into law. He has been in the same post for nearly four years and is in Prime Minister Theresa Mays Cabinet.: SNP members support new currency as soon as practicableSitting in his office in the west end of Edinburgh - two pillows nestle on the sofa, one with a saltire and the other emblazoned with a Union Jack - the MP for Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale  Tweeddale is keen to mention his role in post-devolution politics.However, achievements of the past cannot mask problems of the present. Mundell is at the centre of two constitutional storms that show little sign of settling down.We met twenty four hours after First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced plans for another independence referendum, a policy he vigorously opposes.He is also the Scottish Tory face of Mayrsquos troubled Brexit deal, which has been rejected by MPs on three occasions. Brexit has been delayed and voters will have the opportunity to vote in the European elections next month. The Tories are expecting a drubbing.ldquoItrsquos inevitable now, Mundell says of the elections, wearily. ldquoWersquove run out of time. The reason we are having it is one of the reasons I think many people voted to leave the EU, in the sense that lsquorules are rulesrsquo.Askedhe expected the election would be dficult for his party, he replies: ldquoAll the evidence would suggest that it is going to be a challenge, but wersquove had challenges before.The Governmentrsquos focus is on producing an alternative set of proposals that could command the support of MPs. With Tory right wingers opposed to Mayrsquos deal, the Prime Minister has turned to Labour, who are demanding a customs union.Mundell has previously said the Government would be ldquowilling to discuss such a proposal. However, would he be willing to discuss having a confirmatory vote, which would pit Mayrsquos deal against Remain in another referendum ldquoThe Government doesnrsquot support a confirmatory vote. I donrsquot support a confirmatory vote. Wersquove had two attempts to bring that forward in the House of Commons, he says.ldquoMy personal view is that there is not a majority of MPs in the House of Commons for a confirmatory vote. I donrsquot think there is a logic to it.Mundell campaigned for Remain in  and is known to have a disregard for some of his more bloody-minded Brexiteer colleagues.I have three shots at asking him how he would vote in the event of a second referendum,the choice was between Mayrsquos plan and Remain.ldquoI want to respect the outcome of the referendum wersquove had, so I donrsquot want there to be another referendum, he says. That was a dodge.I press again. Would he back Mayrsquos deal in another referendum  ldquoIrsquom not trying to evade the question. Irsquom clear that her deal is the best deal that is on offer for us to leave the EU. Irsquom clear that we need to respect the outcome of the initial referendum.I ask a dferent version of the same question. Is it possible you could vote Remain ldquoNo, ldquo he says firmly. ldquoI would find it dficult to vote Remain in a future referendum because it would not be respecting the outcome of the previous referendum.Picture of David Mundell by Gordon TerrisI read him recent comments by Scottish Tory MP Stephen Kerr, who said that Tory hardliners displayed the same sort of ldquoromanticised and ldquosometimes xenophobic attitudes as some Scottish nationalists.Mundell appears to concur with his colleaguersquos assessment. ldquoThere are a group of Conservative colleagues whose entire political approach is driven by Brexit, he says.ldquoThey are as obsessive about Brexit as Nicola Sturgeon and some of her colleagues are about independence. Brexit matters to them more than any of the circumstances around it, or other things that are happening.Paul Hutcheon: Nicola Sturgeons route to indyref is through Jeremy CorbynGeorge Osborne, the former Tory chancellor, was revealed recently to have argued against holding an EU referendum before it became Government policy.I ask Mundell, who has always had a pragmatic view on the EU,he was also privately sceptical at that time.ldquoI felt that we had committed to doing it and I felt there wasnrsquot any way of not doing it, having committed to doing it, he says, cryptically.Mundell believes the problem was in the EU reform package Cameron negotiated with European partners ahead of the referendum.If the EU had given more ground, particularly on freedom of movement, Mundell believes this could have shted the dial.ldquoIf David Cameron had been able to secure a dferent package, a better package...that might have ended up dferently.Mundell was an early supporter of Cameron. He backed his leadership bid in  and warmed to his social liberalism. However, Cameronrsquos stock has plummeted after becoming the unwitting architect of a policy - Brexit - he never wanted.He says he has ldquono regrets about voting for Cameron, but concedes the former Prime Minister may have a problem with his legacy.ldquoAs at this moment, he is defined by that referendum and the result, he says.ldquoIn ten years time, we will be able to make that judgement, as to whether that is entirely the dominant feature, in the way that the Iraq war has become Tony Blairrsquos legacy.ldquoWhether we see David Cameron solely in that context or not, I donrsquot know. I hope not.Tory MSPs are becoming increasingly restless about the Brexit farce. Their party made impressive gains at the last general election and are focused on trying to win the Holyrood poll in . Does Mundell believe Brexit is harming Ruth Davidsonrsquos chances of becoming First Minister ldquoI donrsquot think it is, because Ruth will very clearly in the  election set out to people what the clear choice in that election is, which is Nicola Sturgeon continuing as First Minister, independence and a threat of a referendum never going away, compared to Ruthrsquos offer, he says.Mundell is also taking an interest in who will succeed May, given that she wonrsquot contest the next general election:He wants the next Tory leader to have a strong commitment to the Union and be socially liberal: ldquoI want somebody who has a modern outlook and who is in touch with modern le, and how people live their lives.Boris Johnson, who has caused major problems for May, will not be his choice. Mundell has already ruled out serving in a Johnson Cabinet and aims a few more darts in his direction:ldquoI donrsquot think that he is someone who does particularly gel in Scotland.Mundell says Johnson has not had many dealings with Scotland, other than an ldquoill-fated tilt at becoming Edinburgh Universityrsquos rector:ldquoHe has not dipped his toe signicantly into the Scottish political scene. He is not necessarily somebody who has an obvious affinity with Scotland.Mundellrsquos analysis on the attributes of the next leader may be persuasive, but his comments on social liberalism niggle.In the very early days of the Scottish Parliament, when Mundell was a Tory MSP, his party launched a nasty campaign opposing the repeal of anti-gay legislation relating to schools.: SNP councillor snubbed as candidate after being quizzed on Salmond-Sturgeon rtMundell, who later came out as gay, voted against the repeal of what was then called Section . Does he regret how he voted ldquoIt was a point in time. To me, now, it does very much look like history, the way in which that unfolded, he says.Can he see why the LGBT community would be bitter about this episode ldquoI can understand why people can turn their focus backward, but I think itrsquos better to think of actually what has been achieved in that period. What has been achieved in that period of twenty years has [been] a wholesale change in attitude, here in Scotland and across the UK, he replies.Back to the day job, his Cabinet colleague David Liddington last week ruled out a second independence referendum - by way of sanctioning a Section  order - before .Mundell goes further. Askedhe could ever imagine a Tory Government agreeing a section  order, he says:ldquoNo, I canrsquot envisage that circumstance.He then softens slightly: ldquoWersquove had a referendum. It was to be a once-in-a-generation event. Now we could have a debate about how long a generation is, but not in the forseeable future.His view is a minority Labour Government, led by Corbyn, is the biggest threat to the Union.ldquoCorbyn is Nicolarsquos route to a referendum. Itrsquos the only route to a referendum.Mundell, as the longest-serving Scottish Secretary since Ian Lang in the s, is a canny political operator who has helped add to the powers of the Parliament. Whether his legacy survives the winds of Brexit and independence remains to be seen.BIOGRAPHY - : Tory MSP for South of Scotland - present day: Tory MP for Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale - : Shadow Secretary of State for Scotland - : Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Scotland - present day: Secretary of State for Scotland

title: plans-for-a-glasgow-metro-network-and-central-queen-street-tunnel-unveiled
story: The Glasgow Connectivity Commission, established by council leader Susan Aitken in , has put forward a series of bold proposals to boost the cityrsquos economic performance and reconnect ldquoleft-behind areas.:Full details: Report recommends creation of cross-city GlasgowsystemThese include the creation of a Glasgowsystem which would revive abandoned rail routes as well as creating a brand new link connecting the airport to Renfrew, Braehead, Queen Elizabeth University Hospital and the city centre.Meanwhile, a tunnel burrowing under the Clyde and across the city centre promises to transform rail services throughout the central belt by plugging the existing gap between Queen Street and Central stations ndash and creating a ldquotruly comprehensive regional express rail network.Professor David Begg, chair of the Commission, insisted the pound billion proposals ndash which would be delivered over two decades at a cost of pound million a year ndash were ldquoambitious and achievable.:Map shows radical plans for proposed GlasgownetworkIn his introduction to the new report, he writes: ldquoWe do not underestimate the challenges required to implement this reportrsquos ambitious proposals.ldquoBut we also believe they are affordable, deliverable and necessaryScotland wants to achieve its goal of fostering sustainable and inclusive economic growth.It comes after the Commission put forward plans to ldquoradically transform Glasgow city centre last year, giving greater priority to pedestrians and allowing for the creation of public spaces "worthy of a great European city".Its second report examines long-term changes to Glasgowrsquos road and rail network with the potential to change the face of the city forever.As well as theservice and new tunnel, it recommends preparing Glasgow Central for high-speed rail services, extending the station over the Clyde and creating a new southern concourse. This would eventually pave the way for train journeys of less than three hours between Glasgow and London.Meanwhile, a regional transport authority would be created to coordinate land planning and investment, while plans for bus priority on Glasgowrsquos motorway network would boost journey times and reliability and reduce overall traffic volumes.The report also considers new methods of road charging, replacing fuel duty ndash which is currently worth pound billion ndash to prepare for the sht to electric and self-driving vehicles.Transport Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the proposals, and insisted they would be considered as part of a wider assessment of transport needs.He said: ldquoScotlandrsquos transport networks support our economy and day to day activities and it is encouraging to see our largest city giving full consideration to what a future system could offer its citizens.ldquoThe Commissionrsquos report is timely as Transport Scotland takes forward a nationwide assessment of transport requirements with work on an updated National Transport Strategy and the second Strategic Transport Projects Review underway.:Revealed: Plans to reduce cars in Glasgow city to transform streetsldquoWe will consider these recommendations as part of our appraisal, allowing us to balance the needs of communities around the country.Susan Aitken, leader of Glasgow City Council, said: ldquoBack in late  I tasked the Commissioners with delivering a vision for Glasgow which was bold, ambitious and transformative and that is exactly what they have done.ldquoThese proposals are worthy of detailed consideration. This is the kind of thinking which Glasgow has needed and itrsquos clear that the Connectivity Commission has benefited from a very high calibre of evidence and expertise.ldquoThese recommendations have the potential to deliver the kind of inclusive and sustainable economic growth the City Government is committed to, to give Glasgow a competitive edge it needs to compete globally and provide the transport networks the citizens of Glasgow and beyond deserve.

title: indyref2-wont-happen-on-sturgeons-timetable-says-salmond-adviser
story: Kevin Pringle, who was a senior special adviser to the former First Minister, predicted there would not be a new vote by May  because the UK government would block it.He also said there was not enough time to hold and win a referendum regardless.He warned that by talking up ldquoa vote that isnrsquot taking place there was a risk the SNP would ldquoblur the focus on winning another pro-independence majority at Holyrood.:SNP members support new currency as soon as practicableMr Pringle, a former head of communications for the SNP, is one of the most respected political brains in Scotland, and his comments are a blow to the First Minister.Ms Sturgeon last week announced she wanted to hold a new referendum within the next two years in order to give the country a way to avoid the economic damage of Brexit.Her Government is to introduce a framework bill at Holyrood setting the rules for such a vote, and she has asked MSPs to pass it by the end of the year.However Ms Sturgeon also admitted the bill alone could not deliver a referendum, and she would need the UK Government to transfer extra powers under a so-called Section  order.Theresa May refused Ms Sturgeonrsquos first request for a Section  order in , and this week her deputy, David Lidington, said another request would also be rebuffed.Iain Macwhirter: Nicola Sturgeon is storing up trouble by talking about an early referendum she cant deliverWriting in the Sunday Times, Mr Pringle said: ldquoMy forecast is that there wonrsquot be another independence referendum this side of the next Holyrood referendum in May , but that the political meteorology points to a fresh vote being held during the parliament thereafter.ldquoThat would be just shy of the last one, which is a reasonable timescale, given how the Brexit process has transformed the nature of the UK that most Scots backed in .He said that, although Mr Sturgeonrsquos referendum bill ldquocertainly ups the ante, it did so ldquoon a referendum that isnrsquot going to happen in the short term.Besides the UK Governmentrsquos opposition, he said: ldquoEvencircumstances at Westminster changed drastically in the forthcoming months, the business of agreeing, legislating, campaigning and finally holding a referendum would take us beyond the next Holyrood election anyway.Instead he said a referendum would depend on the Greens and SNP, elected on a clear mandate, forming a pro-independence majority in .He said: ldquo[That] seems to me to be the strongest mechanism for ensuring another democratic choice on independence otherwise it will be a very long time before the issue can come back.Former SNP MSP: English not a proper language of ScotlandldquoThe risk is that overdoing referendum process now for a vote that isnrsquot taking place blurs the focus that there must be on May .ldquoThat is where Sturgeon needs to set the Yes movementrsquos sights.ldquoPolls show that a majority for independence isnrsquot far away, and I believe lsquoyesrsquo will win when the question is next put.A new Panelbase poll for the Sunday Times suggested the SNP on course to win  MSPs and the Greens seven at the next Holyrood election, a combined majority of five.The SNP has been asked for comment.

title: full-details-report-recommends-creation-of-cross-city-glasgow-metro-system
story: But the experts and officials behind a radical bid to transform Glasgowrsquos transport offering insist it is not only feasible ndash but necessary.Blueprints unveiled today would see the creation of a comprehensivesystem serving as much of the city as possible, as well as proposals to link the rail networks around Central and Queen Street stations using a new tunnel.:Plans for a Glasgownetwork and Central-Queen Street tunnel unveiledElsewhere, a major extension of Central station out over the Clyde would prepare it for the roll-out of high-speed trains ndash with the eventual aim of supporting a rail service between Glasgow and London with a journey time of less than three hours.It is a hugely ambitious set of proposals expected to cost around pound billion over two decades, or pound million a year.But the Glasgow Connectivity Commission, which has put forward the recommendations, insists they are on a par with similar schemes in other European cities and in line with current spending in Scotland, such as around the Queensferry Crossing and duelling of the A and A roads. It argues its vision would help generate pound. billion a year for the Scottish economy.Professor David Begg, chair of the Commission, said it was easy to baulk at the scale of what is proposed.But he said: ldquoThe proposals we have recommended here will deliver a step-change in Glasgowrsquos economic performance and drive Scotlandrsquos ambitions to deliver stronger, sustainable, inclusive growth.ldquoThey are bold, ambitious and transformative but we are also confident that they are achievable and the right response to secure Glasgowrsquos long-term economic prosperity.Council leaders announced the establishment of the Commission in , with a remit to generate fresh ideas to transform Scotlands biggest city.It is led by Professor Begg, one of the UKrsquos most prominent transport experts, and includes representatives from the Glasgow Chamber of Commerce, Scottish Council for Development and Industry, Transform Scotland and Virgin Trains.In its second report, it argues for a transport overhaul, highlighting the sharp ide in economic opportunity according to access to Glasgowrsquos suburban rail network.It insists the most ldquoglaringly obvious omission in the city is the absence of ldquothe kind of comprehensive, modern rapid transit system serving inner urban destinations that just nearly all of Glasgowrsquos comparator cities have been busy building for the last - years.:First Glasgow shortlisted for six awards at Scottish Transport AwardsGlasgowrsquos subway is the only underground in the world never to have been extended, while its tramway closed completely in . However, many former rail routes remain intact and ready to be reused.The report adds: ldquoThe asset value of this dormant infrastructure could be measured in the billions of pounds, and therefore Glasgow has a ready-made basis for enhanced rapid transit that most cities can only dream about.The first priority of any wider transport strategy, the Commission argues, should be creating a Glasgowsystem, using parts of the existing heavy rail network as well as entirely new sections ndash including some running alongside roads.Meanwhile, old, disused rail routes ndash such as the former Central Low Level Line via the Botanic Gardens to Maryhill ndash would be reopened.The Commission recommends building a link between the airport and Paisley Gilmour Street station by  as the first leg of aline that would then be extended to connect Renfrew ndash the largest town in Scotland without a rail station ndash Braehead Shopping Centre and Queen Elizabeth University Hospital to the city centre.Over the next two decades, this route could then be extended across the city.Elsewhere, a ldquostrategic intervention is required to make Glasgow ready for high-speed rail.The only credible option, the report suggests, is to redesign and revamp Central station. This would require, at the very least, the extension of the station over the River Clyde and the creation of a new southern entrance and concourse roughly on the site of the former Bridge Street station.Meanwhile, the Commission advocates ldquoplugging the gap between Queen Street and Central stations to permanently rid Glasgow of the barrier ldquoimposed by the separation of the cityrsquos two main railway stations.This would involve delivering on longstanding proposals to construct a new tunnel linking the existing rail networks on either side of the Clyde.The most straightforward option, the report argues, is for a tunnel to cut across the city centre, starting from the Shields Road area to the south of the Clyde and continuing north, before joining the existing rail network near Cowlairs. A new, two- underground station between Central and Queen Street would give access to the line.This option would provide around  trains an hour across the city and transform rail services throughout Scotlandrsquos central belt, while a new station at Cowlairs could be ldquothe centrepiece of an extended major redevelopment area.More ambitious plans for ldquotunnelled junctions on either side of the city centre could further revolutionise services, creating a ldquotruly comprehensive regional express rail network.While the most dramatic proposals in the report focus on rail, it also suggests moves to prioritise buses on Glasgowrsquos motorways to improve journey times and reduce traffic congestion.Meanwhile, it argues Scotland should "lead the way" when it comes to preparing for the sht to electric and self-driving vehicles. With fuel duty receipts expected to plummet, new ways to pay for road use will need to be found.Susan Aitken, leader of Glasgow City Council, said the blueprint had the potential to boost economic growth and give Glasgow the competitive edge it needs to compete globally.Mark Johnston, managing director of Glasgow Airport, said the "ambition for a city-wide metro system starting at the airport is forward thinking and could address some of the major transport issues facing the city region".He added: ldquoWe agree with the Commissionrsquos calls for the airport link to be delivered by  which will require firm commitments from the relevant organisations. The airport looks forward to receiving further details.

title: who-watches-the-watchmen-glasgow-urged-to-let-public-see-how-it-plans-to-use-12m-face-scan-cctv-system
story: June th has been selected as Surveillance Camera Day and councils are being urged to throw their doors open so people can see how they operate at first hand.The call comes as Community Safety Glasgow, part of Glasgow City Council, is facing scrutiny over a pound.m lsquofacial recognitionrsquo system which has been installed on  CCTV cameras across the city.The awareness-raising day is an initiative by the Surveillance Camera Commissionerand the Centre for Research into Information, Surveillance and Privacy .:Campaigner accuses Glasgow of squandering pound.m on white elephant surveillance systemThe Commissioner Tony Porterrsquos role is governed by the Home Office but he has no remit in Scotland. However human rights lawyer John Scott QC said it would make sense for Glasgow to take part in Surveillance Camera Day.ldquoI think it would be a good idea for Community Safety Glasgow to let people see what this can do, it might offer a degree of reassurance.ldquoOne of the things this software is used for is identying or locating missing people ndash someone with dementia for instance, as well as recording and tracking people suspected of involvement in crime. So there are elements people would be delighted to hear about as well as other uses where people might feel they are not sure we should have that level of surveillance without more discussion, he said.Mr Porter said the intention of his initiative was to get the public thinking about the use of CCTV and generate debate. He added: ldquoOf particular importance, is the pressing need for a nationwide conversation about how camera technology is evolving, especially around automatic face recognition and articial intelligence and how surveillance cameras are actually used in practice, why theyrsquore used and who is using them.He urged all councils to be more open about such technologies. ldquoThis conversation is important, because we are all captured by the gaze of the camera lens and because surveillance camera systems are meant to be delivered in the public interest, he said.:Big Brother fear as CCTV to use face scanning softwareIn a report from the SCC on facial recognition, he also said such technologies had benefits but also ldquosignicant capabilities to intrude upon the right to privacy, the freedom of assembly and association, the freedom of expression and other fundamental freedoms.Legislation to establish a new Scottish Biometrics Commissioner, whose remit would include Police use of facial recognition technology is expected later this year, following a review chaired by Mr Scott which reported last November.

title: campaign-aims-to-boost-visitor-numbers-in-the-borders
story: Roman legions tramped on a bloody commute between Hadrianrsquos Wall in the south and the Antonine Wall in the north. Later, peaceful monks built lavish th century abbeys, perhaps a little at odds with their simplistic le.But while the Scottish Borders holds its own when it comes to history and landscape, for years it has been largely overlooked by tourists on their way to Edinburgh and the Highlands.Now, in a bid to capture a slice of Scotlandrsquos tourism boom,  of the regionrsquos historic homes and castles have drawn inspiration from the popularity of Munro bagging to create their own lsquobag a big housersquo challenge.Unlike the physical effort of scaling a  feet mountain -particularly tricky as there are none in the Borders - all lsquobaggersrsquo have to do is follow a map, take in some sumptuous stately home surroundings, maybe even enjoy a cream tea as they go, and tick off their achievement on a new illustrated map.As they progress, visitors receive a stamp to prove theyrsquove lsquobagged a big housersquo.Itrsquos hoped the idea by local group Big Houses in the Scottish Borders, combined with other initiatives, can help reverse a tourism slump that has seen domestic visitor numbers to the area crash by a third since  and international figures halve over the same period.According to Lady Catherine Maxwell-Stuart, a direct descendant of the Stuart kings and whose family has occupied one of the properties included in the initiative - Traquair House, near Peebles - for over  years, the region is perceived by many international tourists as too close to its English neighbour to be regarded as ldquoreal Scotland.She said: ldquoItrsquos not that we have been complacent but, because we are called the Scottish Borders, overseas visitors donrsquot think they will be in the lsquorealrsquo Scotland.ldquoThey think this is a halfway house, and theyrsquore in a rush to get to the Highlands and what they think is real Scotland.ldquoWe want to remind them they are entering Scotland when they come here ndash this is the beginning of Scotland.The flood of tourists to Scotlandrsquos lsquohoneypotrsquo destinations such as Edinburgh, west coast islands like Skye and the increasingly popular NC route is causing increasing concern that other areas are missing out.Last month Peter Irvine, author of Scotland the Best and creator of Edinburghs organised Hogmanay celebrations, warned the capital has an "over-tourism" problem on a par with Barcelona and Venice.He called for national tourism body VisitScotland to focus more on promoting other areas, such as the Scottish Borders and Dumfries and Galloway.Both regions are currently part of a two-year VisitScotland campaign - See South Scotland ndash which has received pound, of additional Scottish Government funding to help drive up visitor numbers.However, the challenge is signicant: VisitScotland figures issued last month for the area showed the , international visitors to the Scottish Borders in  represented just % of the national total, while the , domestic visitors made up only %.Lady Maxwell Stuart said that, while the area has suffered, the recently opened Borders Railway was helping to alter perceptions.ldquoThere was a tendency for people in the central belt to see the Borders as a million miles away. Therersquos now a view that the Borders are a bit easier to get to," she added.ldquoIn the past, VisitScotland has tended to ignore the south a little bit. Wersquore hoping the new campaign is helping to spread the message.The Bag the Big Houses scheme includes an illustrated map to guide visitors to grand homes and castles.Gillian Steele, chair of Big Houses in the Scottish Borders, the group behind the lsquobag a housersquo idea, said: ldquoWe have a stunning collection of properties for visitors to experience and we want to encourage people to visit as many as they can, and spend more time here in the beautul Scottish Borders.VisitScotland analysis of Borders tourism issued last month revealed the areaachieved just % occupancy level in , while bed and breakfast accommodation struggled with just %. Spending in the region by international tourists plummeted from poundm in  to just poundm in .Paula Ward, VisitScotland Regional Leadership Director, welcomed the new initiative. She said: ldquoThis is an exciting project bringing together all of these beautul buildings in the Scottish Borders.ldquoThe launch of this new initiative is a great example of attractions working together to attract more visitors to delve into the past and discover some of the hidden gems and fascinating stories that the Scottish Borders is famous for.

title: letters-indyref-2-must-come-as-a-two-vote-package
story: The clamour for a confirmatory vote also reflects where current academic thinking on referendums is coalescing around.The Independent Commission on Referendums ndash the gold standard academic authority on referendums, recommends that any future Scottish independence referendum should come as a two-vote package. This should be set out clearly in the White Paper preceding the first vote, alerting the electorate to the fact that the SNP Government would have the right to call a confirmatory referendumthere had been a material change between what was promised in the independence manesto and what was delivered after the final separation talks had been signed off between Westminster and Holyrood.The confirmatory vote opens a new line of debate as to what constitutes a material change. Lets apply the confirmatory vote retrospectively to the last independence referendum. Would a drop in the price of a barrel of Brent crude from  in September  to around  per barrel on independence dayconstitute a material change  Of course it would have, especially as the whole independence economic case was predicated around a barrel of oil being .What independence supporters are really asking for when they demand indyref now, is a rerun of the one-vote  referendum. They are in for a shock, as Brexit has now rendered a one-off referendum option for any future indyref  as obsolete, The strategically inept First Minister, who has been clamouring for a confirmatory vote for the EU referendum would be accused of brazen hypocrisya second Edinburgh Agreement didnt include a two-vote indyref package.What a confirmatory vote means in reality for indyref is that the next economic case for independence will have to be absolutely rock solid and be able to sustain - years or so of the most intense in-depth critical scrutiny until the final deal between Westminster and Holyrood is agreed. The portents for this happening do not look good. The SNP-endorsed Growth Commissions recommendations for an independent Scotlands economic future was three years in the making and it took a non-economist three days after its publication to expose its major failings. Failings which have since been endorsed by a slew of economists as an accurate analysis of the Growth Commissions weaknesses,Unlike September  it will no longer be possible for the SNP to punt a weak economic case to the electorate in any future independence referendum as the electorate will now be able to scrutinise what was promised before the first vote and compare it to what was signed off on independence day.Could it be that a confirmatory vote has raised the bar of public scrutiny so high now that it might mean that the referendum route to Scottish Independence is now closed, due to a perennially weak economic case Robert Hoskins, Parkhill Road, Shawlands, Glasgow.Read more: Scottish independence: How and when Scotland could rejoin the EUAFTER much preicating Nicola Sturgeon has announcedthat a second referendum vote "should" be held within the next two years to "protect" Scotland against Brexit. She went on to suggest that a choice between Brexit and a future for Scotland as an independent European nation should be on offer. What absolute balderdash.First, most people would accept that eventhe UK leaves the EU as in a "soft" Brexit, it will be very challenging, but at least Britain has its own currency, a very low fiscal deficit and has many years of experience exportingto countries under WTO-based rules. Scotland on the other hand has the worst fiscal deficitin all the OECD countries, does not have its own currency and relies on selling around  per cent of its goods and services direct to the rUK internal market ndash whereas it is only around six per cent the other way round.Furthermore, the idea we can simply leave our -year-Union and "cook the books"in order to meet the strict EU criteria for new joining countries is complete fantasy. Not only would we have to wait an indeterminable time to join the EUall new members are required to join the euro, creating decades of economic uncertainty. Nicola Sturgeon loves to talk about a "clf edge" ndash given her aim is to be outside the UK and EU markets at the same time I now know exactly what she means. No, thanks .Ian Lakin,Pinelands, Murtle Den Road, Milltimber, Aberdeen.KEITH Howellwrites that Nicola Sturgeonrsquos plan to hold a second referendum ldquois no more than playing to the nationalist gallery ahead of this weekendrsquos SNP Conference. His speculation is a bit fancul, as the SNP has been calling for advancement in the Brexit shambles, and this will chivvy along the English Tory and Labour parties, while they continue to ignore ScotlandLord North has been named by some as the worst Prime Minister ever as his indolence in office led to the loss of the American Colonies Mrs Theresa May is now rivalling this description.Once the dust of Brexit has settled, I hazard a guess that she might adopt the soubriquet of ldquoLady South for her peerage.Jim Lynch, Corstorphine Hill Crescent, Edinburgh.BROWSING my iPhone in a waiting room recently, I spotted in the Letters section of The Herald either letters from the usual suspects, lambasting the SNP, or references to them. It occurred to me that ldquovexatious might explain their motivation.The definitions included: Annoyance, frustration, irritability, irritation, exasperation, anger, rage, fury, temper, bad temper, hot temper, wrath, spleen, chagrin, pique, crossness, indignation, displeasure, discontent, dissatisfaction, disgruntlement, ill humour, peevishness, resentment, and umbrage.I challenge any or all of the candidates to volunteer which one, or several, of these definitions best suit their inidual temperaments, or is it simply a collective case of sheer detestation of the SNP Douglas R Mayer, Thomson Crescent, Currie.

title: european-election-results-can-help-nicola-sturgeon-in-push-for-scottish-independence
story: At one end of the spectrum, the SNP and the Greens want two, one on Brexit and one on independence. At the other end the Conservatives, UKIP and the Brexit Party do not want a referendum on either subject.In between are, first, the Liberal Democratswho would like another referendum on Brexit but not on independence and, second, the Labour party who are clear they oppose another ballot on independence but are neither definitely for or against another Brexit ballot.:Sturgeon warns party must convince voters Scottish independence will not damage economyConsequently, whatever may be the position where in the UK, in Scotland the Euro-elections will be about more than Brexit. They will also be the occasion for another round in Scotlandrsquos continuing constitutional debate, especially given that last week the First Minister re-affirmed her wish to hold another independence referendum sooner rather than later. But what will be the impact of this double fault line Are not all of the parties at risk of chasing no more than relatively small niche markets  After all, in the last Euro-elections in , held before the UKrsquos membership of the EU had become such a live issue , no party won as much as % of the vote and only the SNP and Labour secured more than %.The potentially cross-cutting nature of the two debates was very clear at the time of the EU referendum. Even though the SNPrsquos vision of independence has for nearly thirty years been one of independence inside the European Union, as many as one in three of those who voted Yes in  backed Leave .The unionist camp was ided on Brexit too, with just over two-fth of those who voted No backing Leave. No single combination of independence and Brexit support represented more than % of voters.Yet two polls published at the weekend both suggested that the SNP was heading for as much as % or so of the vote, more or less in line with its current popularity for both Westminster and Holyrood. Rather than simply winning much more than a niche market, the party seems set for its best performance yet in a Euro-election.The explanation lies in the fact that, these days, the SNP not only dominates among Yes voters in a way that it never did before the  but also has become very much the most favoured party among Remainers north of the border. Thus, while as many as two-thirds of those who voted Yes in  say they will vote for the SNP next month, so also do almost a half of those who voted Remain.Either pattern on its own is enough to secure the SNP at least % of the vote. Meanwhile, not every voter fits the general pattern and, despite the partyrsquos stance on Brexit and independence, around one on five Leave voters and about one in eight No voters also say they will back Nicola Sturgeonrsquos party.True, even many SNP voters are doubtful about the idea of holding another independence referendum as quickly as Ms Sturgeon has in mind. However, nine in ten are in favour of holding one at some point in the future. For most SNP supporters the question is an issue of timing rather than one of principle and seems unlikely to motivate them to change their minds.Butthe SNP are able to win over much more than a niche market, nobody  is able to do so. For a start, not only does the SNPrsquos popularity among Remain voters leave little more than crumbs left for their fellow supporters of a second EU referendum - the Liberal Democrats, Change UK, and the Greens - but it also means that, in contrast to the position south of the border, support for Labour among Remain votersis only modestly higher than it is among Leave supporters . This does not make it any easier for the party to mount a performance that might mark a recovery in the partyrsquos fortunes.Even so, there would still seem to be plenty of room for a party that stands for both Brexit and the Union.:Scottish independence poll: One in five Scots back Nicola Sturgeons Indyref planBut while that might be how the Conservatives think of themselves, their failure to deliver the former means the formula that served the party so well in  no longer does so now.The initial Euro-polling suggests that only just over in fiveof those who voted Leave will back the party on May . Even many a Leaver voter who would still be loyal to the party in a Holyrood or Westminster election indicates that they will not back it for the Euros.They are minded instead to protest against the UK governmentrsquos failure to deliver Brexit by voting for Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party. It already seems to be the single most popular party among Leave voters, albeit still only backed by no more than one in three, and seems to be in with a good chance of winning one of the six seats that will be up for grabs, matching UKIPrsquos achievement in .A Conservative collapse, a weakened Labour party, and the unionist vote scattered to the four winds. story: Celtic fans have paid tribute to Stevie Chalmers following his death, aged .Chalmersscored the most famous goal in Celtic history, a goal which secured the European Cup for Celtic, who became the first British club to win the trophy.:Celtic legend and Lisbon Lion Stevie Chalmers dies aged It came on the th May,  at the Estadio Nacional in Lisbon. story: Skyle will be Aberdeen International Airportrsquos official FREE customer magazine and will serve as a guide to travel, lestyle and business for passengers and destinations both at home and abroad with a key focus on Aberdeen as a city.:Aberdeen airport appoints Steve Szalay as new MDIt will highlight the many destinations available from the airport along with cultural aspects of the city and promote Aberdeenshire as a vibrant, growing tourism haven for visitors from both home and overseas. title: six-ways-to-show-pets-the-love-they-deserve
story: The Dog Lover Show The Dog Lover Show is back at the SEC on th  th September, bigger and better with more dogs, more performances and more exhibitors.Whether you own a dog, plan to rescue or adopt or just love dogs, The Dog Lover Show is going to be your perfect day out. The main stage has non-stop action with audience participation and plenty to entertain big and little kids alike.Meet Golden Retrievers to Great Danes, Lhasa Apso to Labradors, from Keeshonds to Braque Du Bourbonnais, common to rare and even some endangered breeds.On the main stage Scotlandrsquos fastest flyball team s, as do Mordor Gun Dogs display, and watch stunts, agility and performances from some of the most talented dogs in the UK.There are still more exciting performances and features to be announced plus Still Games lsquoMark Coxrsquo is compere for the weekend, adding some humour to what is already an action packed, fun filled day out for all the family.Kids up to yrs are admitted free and Early Bird Tickets are available for a limited time at pound for Adults and pound Children.Visit www.thedoglovershow for more information on the show or visit the Facebook page.www.facebook thedoglovershow ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------Edinburgh Dog and Cat HomeEdinburgh Dog and Cat Home is offering free information sessions to groups, clubs and organisations throughout Edinburgh and the Lothians.This follows the Homersquos launch of a new education programme earlier in , made possible by a grant awarded to the Home by The Kennel Club Educational Trust, and supported by a further grant from RS Macdonald Charitable Trust. Workshops have been in high demand and extremely well received by schools since its launch, with every teacher surveyed citing an increased understanding of the work of the Home and responsible pet ownership.The Home is now offering adapted workshops to community organisations, from sports clubs to rotary groups, to share more about the work of Edinburgh Dog and Cat Home and its -year history. Workshops can also be tailored to address inidual topics on request.Edinburgh Dog and Cat Homersquos Education Officer, Daniel Tipping, said:ldquoItrsquos been brilliant to speak to so many young people this year, but Irsquom looking forward to sharing more with others in the community, too. Despite having been at our Seafield site for over  years, Irsquom constantly hearing people say that theyrsquove always wondered about what goes on behind the scenes. To arrange a booking or for further information, email Daniel at education@edch.org.uk.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------Argyll HolidaysCan a family holiday really be a family holidayyou have to leave someone ndash particularly someone with four legs ndash behind  Probably not. Thatrsquos why Argyll Holidays take pride in creating great holiday memories for the entire family, including your pets.Based in stunning Argyllshire, Argyll Holidays can offer the perfect base for your pet friendly getaway. title: research-reveals-the-top-50-things-that-get-brits-hot-under-the-collar
story: Researchers revealed long queues, loud roadworks and train delays are also among some of the most irritating things in modern le which get our blood boiling.A third of Brits canrsquot stand when motorists donrsquot use their indicators when making a turn, and  per cent have felt their temper flare when hearing someone talking about them behind their back.As a result of these annoying moments, the average Brit will feel angry or frustrated five times a week.And with each spell of anger lasting an average of  minutes, this means the typical Brit will spend an hour and  minutes each week surrounded by the red mist.Though one in eight claim they never get angry or frustrated.A spokesperson for Andrews Sykes, which commissioned the study, said: ldquoEven with the best intentions in the world we are likely to spend hours or days of our lives feeling angry, frustrated and generally lsquohot under the collarrsquo.Read more: full study resultsldquoLe is unpredictable, and many of these unfortunate circumstances which lead us to anger or embarrassment are caused by others, who might not realise theyrsquore doing anything wrong at all.TOP  THINGS WHICH GET BRITS lsquoHOT UNDER THE COLLARrsquo. Drivers who dont use their indicators. Queuing for a long time. Losing your wallet. Cyclists who donrsquot obey the Highway Code such as skipping red traffic lights. Being sat in traffic. Falling over tripping in public. When you break something in a moment of stupidity. Having to ask people for money they owe you. Roadworks. Train delays. Finding out someone has been talking about you. Coming out of a toilet someone  has made a terrible stench in, then finding someone waiting outside who will think it was you. Bumping your nice car. Waiting for other people to make a decision. Someone bailing on plans yoursquove had for ages. Waiting for someone to get ready. When you are trying to follow a sat nav which keeps taking you the wrong way. Finding out your friends met up and you werent invited. Bank fees. Building flat pack furniture. Watching a sex scene in a film with your parents. Seeing a photograph where you dont look your best. Being the first person to arrive somewhere and having to sit alone for ages. Hearing other parents swear in front of your children. Calling someone by the wrong name and finding out afterwards that you made the mistake.. Being asked your weight. Having to get changed in a public space such as at the gym or swimming pool. Trying to get through tourists in London. Talking about money - savings, salary etc. Realising youve had a piece of food in your teeth for most of the afternoon. When a colleague doesnrsquot deliver their work on time. Realising you are the fattest person among your friends on a night out. Someone who has been at the company for less time than you getting promoted. Being asked how many people yoursquove had sex with. When on public transport. Interest rate rises. Someone pointing out your flies are undone. When your team lose and their bitter rivals win. Walking out of the toilet with tissue paper stuck to your shoe. When its a hot day and the building you are in has the air con turned up so you are actually cold. Your parents talking about sex in any capacity. Finding out you have been kept out of the loop with client emails. Finding out the boss has been favouring someone . Someone revealing the football score before yoursquove had a chance to watch it. Being made a sub-standard cup of tea. When people talk about TV shows in the office but yoursquore an episode behind. Someone sending you an indecent photo. Forgetting to close the last specialist interest web page you looked at on your phone, then someone borrows it to google something. Being asked your dress size. Being asked your ageThe study also found strangers are most likely to be the cause of the nationrsquos frustrations, followed by annoying partners and irritating kids.And  per cent of Brits think they are more likely to lose their rag with someone after a bad day at work.A third of Brits admit they are often quick to anger, and  per cent have found themselves having to stop to take a breath, count to  and calm down when their rage becomes too much.Forty one per cent have been so hot under the collar in a confrontation with someone they have had to walk away in silence to themselves.It also emerged one in four find it best to calm their fires with a cup of tea, and  per cent shut their eyes and go to lsquoa happy placersquo.But as well as anger causing their face to turn red, the average Brit will also turn scarlet due to embarrassment twice a week, or  times a year.Brits reckon their partner is most likely to make them feel embarrassed, followed by their kids.And of the parents surveyed, two thirds believe they have become more prone to embarrassment since having their children.Fty-six per cent of the , Brits polled literally blush ndash going pink in the face ndash when they are feeling embarrassed.And  per cent of these blushers feel only more embarrassed when someone points out their flushed cheeks.A spokesperson for Andrews Sykes added: ldquoWhether hot under the collar or red in the face, it has been interesting exploring the aspects of Britsrsquo lives most likely to make us act irrationally.ldquoIt is also good to discover the one in eight Brits who are able to keep a cool head even in the most frustrating circumstances, and the three in five who take embarrassing situations in good humour.

title: a-hard-brexit-could-push-scottish-independence-over-the-line-says-tony-blair
story: In an interview with the Institute for Government think-tank to mark the th anniversary of Scottish devolution, the former Labour Prime Minister, whose government instigated the major constitutional reform in , suggested Nicola Sturgeonrsquos SNP misunderstood the concept of nationhood.ldquoScotland as an independent country would immediately lose its ability to influence things through membership of the UK, declared the former PM.ldquoI always say that the arguments of the Brexiteers are very similar to the arguments of the Scottish Nationalists ultimately. Itrsquos just a misunderstanding of what nationhood really entails in the st century.Read more:European election results can help Nicola Sturgeon in push for Scottish independenceMr Blair told the IoG that people in the UK should think more carefully about how they had a British and UK identity and not just an English, Scottish, Irish and Welsh one.ldquoThatrsquos important. People used to think it was a bit trivial when I used to say we should put the football leagues togetherhellipItrsquos just you need to find ways in which people are realising they have a lot in common, as well as space for the ersity of the UK. Irsquod do a lot more of that.He explained how once devolution occurred, even institutions like the BBC ldquobecame separated in a very clear way. You just lost that sense of a common agenda that you are waking up to every day. Obviously, thatrsquos now happenedhellipWe need to be more active and passionate in our defence of the Union. And maybeone good thing comes out, once we get rid of this Brexit thing, is that we really need to think about what is the place of the UK in the world and why is it sensible for countries to be together in the UK.Reflecting on the two decades since the first elections to a ldquoreconvened Scottish Parliament, the former PM said it was important for Labour to have succeeded particularly in Scotland, where the support for independence would have been "unstoppable without devolution.He said the issue of Scotlandrsquos future was a continuing debate but noted: ldquoWersquore still the UK and wersquore still together so yoursquove got to put a tick there. Are there still pressures for secession  Well, in Scotland, yes, but I still think they wonrsquot succeed unless Brexit pushes us into a position where that kind of gets Scottish independence over the lineyou have[a] hard Brexit, which is possible.ldquoAnd in Northern Ireland, without Brexit I would be very confident that the Union would stick together but again Brexit is an issue there.Read more:Scottish independence: How and when Scotland could rejoin the EUIt was suggested to Mr Blair thatBrexit happened, it would be very hard to resist demands for a second Scottish independence referendum because the facts would have changed.He replied: ldquoYes, the facts will have changed. I still think we should be very careful doing it[indyref] unless itrsquos clear that therersquos a huge groundswell for it. You know, one of things that Brexit has taught us is the danger of playing around with referendums in our country. These are big decisions which alter the whole nature of the country.And yet the former PM decried David Cameron for not proposing a confirmatory vote on any Brexit deal against the status quo.ldquoItrsquos obviously sensible that once you negotiate a settlement you say: lsquoTell us: do you prefer the house yoursquore in or the house you are moving to rsquo Thatrsquos reasonable.In the interview, Mr Blair referred to the ldquoBrexit imbroglio and decried what he described as English Nationalism within and outwith Westminster.ldquoWhatrsquos weird at the moment is yoursquove got Conservative MPs like the Boris Johnsons, the Rees-Moggs, who say theyrsquore vigorous Unionists but are actually really playing on English Nationalism, he explained.Read more:Polls show almost half of Scots think immigration levels too highldquoIrsquom quite shocked by the amount of people who are Brexiteers in England who, when you put to them that it could cause a strain on the Union, just kind of shrug their shoulders and say: lsquoWell, we donrsquot care.rsquo I mean, itrsquos just really shocking, actually. Because thatrsquos just profoundly ignorant of our history, whatrsquos brought us to here and the way the world is changing outside the UK.In the years following devolution, Mr Blair suggested: ldquoThe most interesting development in Scotland has been the decline of the Labour Party and the resurgence of the Conservative Party. Now, that has been very simply because the Conservatives have spotted a gap in the market that Labour have left pro-Union, pro-reform.The former PM added: ldquoBy the way,  years is not long in a new constitutional settlement. I donrsquot think we can judge devolution properlyhellipprobably for many decades.

title: next-queens-speech-due-in-summer-could-be-put-back-to-autumn-because-of-brexit-suggests-no-10
story: The parliamentary set-piece had been expected this summer. The last Queens Speech was in June , when an extended two-year parliamentary session was introduced to deal with Brexit.But when asked when the next Queens Speech would be, Theresa Mays spokesman said the Government was focused on passing the Withdrawal Agreement Bill [WAB], needed to raty the UK-EU deal."That is part of the current Queens Speech cycle and we need to finish that work," he explained.The spokesman added: "The Government is always bringing forward legislation to allow it to deliver on its agenda. In relation to the current session, obviously it was an extended session to allow us to deliver on Brexit. The work to secure WAB...remains ongoing.It has been suggested the Prime Minister wants to delay a new Queens Speech until the autumn so as to have a better chance of securing the votes needed to pass her legislative agenda.But Pete Wishart for the SNP lashed out, saying: "This latest delay to the Queens Speech shows yet again that the Tories are failing to get on with the day job as lame duck Theresa Mays zombie government limps from chaos to crisis.The Perth MP said the Conservatives were so consumed by Brexit and bereft of any ideas, that they were failing to address the issues that mattered to millions of people from ending Tory austerity to tackling poverty, climate change and the crisis in Englands schools and hospitals."Westminster is utterly broken and has proven itself incapable of standing up for Scotlands interests, declared Mr Wishart, adding: ldquoIn contrast, the SNP Government is taking Scotland forward with ambitious and progressive policies for a fairer and more equal country.

title: pressure-mounts-on-jeremy-corbyn-from-inside-and-outside-labour-to-back-peoples-vote-on-brexit
story: As four trade union chiefs urged the Labour leader to commit the party to a confirmatory vote, so too did the SNPrsquos Ian Blackford and the Liberal Democratsrsquo Vince Cable.The increasing pressure on Mr Corbyn came as a glimmer of hope emerged in the cross-party Brexit talks, now in their fth week.David Lidington, Theresa Mayrsquos de facto deputy, described the latest meeting as ldquopositive" and "productive".The Cabinet Office Minister admitted to being "encouraged" by a sense from both sides about the "need to inject greater urgency" into the talks. He said more meetings would take place later this week.Sue Hayman, the Shadow Environment Secretary, was equally upbeat, saying there had been a "really constructive discussion" as the two parties were "getting much more into the nuts and bolts of the detail".Earlier, Shami Chakrabarti, the Shadow Attorney General, said Labour colleagues involved in the talks had to tell the partys ruling National Executive Committee on Tuesday "whether there is any hope for a sensible Brexit" or the only means of breaking the deadlock was a second referendum or a general election.Thus far, Mr Corbyn has been reluctant to move further on backing another EU poll some colleagues believe it would be a betrayal of the  vote and would harm Labour in some of its key north of England strongholds.But four major union leaders are pressing the party leader to include a second referendum pledge in Labourrsquos Euro poll manesto: Unisonrsquos Dave Prentis the GMBrsquos Tim Roache and USDAWrsquos Paddy Lillis and the TSSA transport unionrsquos Manuel Cortes.The latter said: ldquoFrankly, itrsquos time for our party to act on the overwhelming wishes of its members and votes by pledging to support a confirmatory public vote on any Brexit deal.In a letter to the Labour leader, Mr Blackford warned him that he was ldquofacilitating a Brexit disaster.The Highland MP said: ldquoJeremy Corbyn must stop blocking a second EU referendum and start working with the SNP to prevent Brexit and the lasting harm it will cause.He claimed thatthe Labour leader refused to show leadership on the issue, his party would be just as culpable as the Tories for the damage to jobs, living standards, the economy and public services.In his own letter to Mr Corbyn, Sir Vince urges him to ldquopush for the inclusion of a confirmatory public referendum in your European manesto.Tom Brake, the Lib Demsrsquo Brexit spokesman, added: "It is long overdue that the Leader of the Labour Party backs his own party policy and helps make the final say a reality.Elsewhere, Michel Barnier, the EUrsquos chief Brexit negotiator, said in a speech in Belgium that it was six months since the UK and EU agreed a deal. "We need to fix Brexit quickly, he declared.

The team has worked hard to secure national and local funding to boost the range of activities on offer.”Aberdeenshire Council’s Communities Committee Chair Cllr Anne Stirling added: “The promotion of positive health and well-being is a key aim for Live Le Aberdeenshire.
